text:
I've been working on a graphics programming tool aims to do just that; deconstructing every part of a graphics pipeline, and giving artists all that power in a visual interface.

Main difference between most visual programming tools is that we're relying on standard APIs (like say OpenVDB or any other python/c++ library) and simply creating a visual layer (that has an extensive tagging system to make it easy as hell to find anything you might want) that anyone can interact with.

Your result can be previewed at runtime, converted to code or both. Still quite early in the dev phase, but hopefully will have more shiny stuff to share on this project later this year :slightly_smiling_face:

Your result can be previewed at runtime, converted to code or both. Still quite early in the dev phase, but hopefully will have more shiny stuff to share on this project later this year

text: <@URKL31C2J> yeah I think one of the things that's missing in most visual tools for artists is the ability to easily create new visual workflows\tools\etc in a visual editor.  Working on game teams I found that engineering (aka me) was often the bottleneck for relatively minor UX and workflow changes

elements.text: yeah I think one of the things that's missing in most visual tools for artists is the ability to easily create new visual workflows\tools\etc in a visual editor.  Working on game teams I found that engineering (aka me) was often the bottleneck for relatively minor UX and workflow changes

text: I don't think its a trivial problem

text: and, you're right, in a lot of environments it can be solved with text scripting

text: Those of you interested in programming in VR might want to check out this release <https://store.steampowered.com/app/413750/Turtle_VR/>

attachments.title: Save 10% on Turtle VR on Steam
attachments.text: Turtle VR brings the Logo turtle into the 21st century. Use an interface similar to MIT Scratch, and Google Blockly, to program a turtle to draw your creations within various 3D worlds.
attachments.fallback: Save 10% on Turtle VR on Steam

elements.text: Those of you interested in programming in VR might want to check out this release

text: I'm still disappointed that all VR titles basically use a flat panel\iPad metaphor with Scratch blocks or some list based UI.  I really pushed to get away from that when I was working on Horizon but got way too much friction.  I doubt Horizon will be any better unfortunately, I've been away from the project for 6 months so it's entirely possible that they've moved away from visual scripting entirely or gone with a different paradigm :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Is a lot of text comfortable to read yet on any of the latest-gen headsets? (Haven't tried an Index, for example.)

elements.text: Is a lot of text comfortable to read yet on any of the latest-gen headsets? (Haven't tried an Index, for example.)

text: That's been my issue with any complex UI in VR so far. Ironically the best use case I've found for the HoloLens and Magic Leap "true AR" headsets is reading text off a monitor!

elements.text: That's been my issue with any complex UI in VR so far. Ironically the best use case I've found for the HoloLens and Magic Leap "true AR" headsets is reading text off a monitor!

text: Index is better

elements.text: Index is better

text: Rift S and Quest are better than Rift

elements.text: Rift S and Quest are better than Rift

text: But reading lots of text is still not a pleasant experience

elements.text: But reading lots of text is still not a pleasant experience

text: Future headsets will greatly improve resolution and maybe one day we'll get varifocal which also improves the text reading experience

elements.text: Future headsets will greatly improve resolution and maybe one day we'll get varifocal which also improves the text reading experience

text: There's a nice proof-of-concept app called Enklu that's designed to be used with a HoloLens and a desktop together. You get an environment scan from the HoloLens into the app, use your hands to position stuff in it, and add your game logic at a regular keyboard and monitor that you can see. End product is a QR code you distribute to other HoloLens users who can walk through the scanned location. (Too glitchy for practical use last I tried it, but live updating from a real-world scanned environment synced between two apps is non-trivial!)

elements.text: There's a nice proof-of-concept app called Enklu that's designed to be used with a HoloLens and a desktop together. You get an environment scan from the HoloLens into the app, use your hands to position stuff in it, and add your game logic at a regular keyboard and monitor that you can see. End product is a QR code you distribute to other HoloLens users who can walk through the scanned location. (Too glitchy for practical use last I tried it, but live updating from a real-world scanned environment synced between two apps is non-trivial!)

text: --But yeah I think long term cameras and screens will advance faster than real optics. A couple of the CV-based headsets already allow you to pipe in the camera feed to your own app, although of course it's not yet high-res enough to read text at all, much less comfortably.

elements.text: --But yeah I think long term cameras and screens will advance faster than real optics. A couple of the CV-based headsets already allow you to pipe in the camera feed to your own app, although of course it's not yet high-res enough to read text at all, much less comfortably.

text: I figure the win condition for getting rid of the physical monitor is when the portion of your VR screen that a laptop would take up in your field of view has equivalent resolution.

elements.text: I figure the win condition for getting rid of the physical monitor is when the portion of your VR screen that a laptop would take up in your field of view has equivalent resolution.

text:
Since they've added python support, UE4 has become very flexible actually, and all 3D softwares also have python support for their C++ APIs as well.

In 2016 I basically started publishing really small scripts that improved specific parts of Autodesk Maya, and before I knew it I had over 30K paying users and that's where I really understood that you don't even have to create new frameworks, just give people a better way to interact with existing APIs.

Of course there are always limits to said APIs, which is why we're building C++ libraries (with python bindings) in parallel for more advanced geometry and image processing.

elements.text:
Since they've added python support, UE4 has become very flexible actually, and all 3D softwares also have python support for their C++ APIs as well.

In 2016 I basically started publishing really small scripts that improved specific parts of Autodesk Maya, and before I knew it I had over 30K paying users and that's where I really understood that you don't even have to create new frameworks, just give people a better way to interact with existing APIs.

Of course there are always limits to said APIs, which is why we're building C++ libraries (with python bindings) in parallel for more advanced geometry and image processing.

text:
In the short term the goal is to give people a new way of interacting with code, in the long-term our ecosystem will leverage more APIs built specifically around certain issues that we want to solve.

And the fact that the end result is always standard code means that there's no lock-in to our platform; you can make something you like, share it with your friends and voilà.

We're still a fairly small team (that's hiring CG programmers, btw!) but have secured the funding/structure to make the most out of this project, and hopefully we'll get to share more about it soon! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
In the short term the goal is to give people a new way of interacting with code, in the long-term our ecosystem will leverage more APIs built specifically around certain issues that we want to solve.

And the fact that the end result is always standard code means that there's no lock-in to our platform; you can make something you like, share it with your friends and voilà.

We're still a fairly small team (that's hiring CG programmers, btw!) but have secured the funding/structure to make the most out of this project, and hopefully we'll get to share more about it soon!

text: Rendering text at a distance helps.  We had some readability success in having labels appear at a distance yet composed after the rest of the scene.  As a result, holding an object in front of a label would cause the object to be disappear, but it did make labels (lines of code in this case) easy to read.

elements.text: Rendering text at a distance helps.  We had some readability success in having labels appear at a distance yet composed after the rest of the scene.  As a result, holding an object in front of a label would cause the object to be disappear, but it did make labels (lines of code in this case) easy to read.
